Frequently asked questions regarding employee rights
What does it mean to stay home

li.description: Convincing your loved ones to stay home can be a challenge. Here are some tips on having a conversation about staying home and staying healthy.

a.title: Convincing your loved ones to stay home can be a challenge. Here are some tips on having a conversation about staying home and staying healthy.

li.a: Talking to loved ones about the importance of staying home
El gobernador Inslee anuncia la orden de "Permanecer en sus hogares y mantener la salud"

section.class: homepage-block-3 col-xl-9 col-lg-9 col-md-9 col-sm-12 col-xs-12 block block-block-content block-block-content114d07f8-17c4-42e2-adad-96c5cb63bac7 clearfix

p.br: Daily statistics are provided by the Department of Health (DOH) or view statewide statistics on a map.
Spanish: Nuevo coronavirus, BienestarWA, Chinese 中文, Russian: Pусский, Vietnamese: Vi-rút Corona Mới, Korean: 한국어, more translations...

p.strong: Need a phone number to call with questions about the virus?
p.br: DOH operates a hotline, with multiple language assistance, from 6 a.m. to 10 p.m. daily at 1-800-525-0127. The call center cannot access COVID-19 testing results. You can also text the word “Coronavirus” to 211-211 to receive information and updates on your phone.

p.strong: Guidance for complying with the Stay Home, Stay Healthy order
p.br: Guidance for businesses who want to request inclusion and individuals who want to report suspected violations and those who want to report evictions as part of the Stay Home, Stay Healthy order.

section.class: col-xl-3 col-lg-3 col-md-3 col-sm-12 col-xs-12 block block-block-content block-block-content5857d471-e796-4249-b89d-dd9f723eb3d2 clearfix

ul.li: Learn more about face masks or cloth face coverings and how to make them
How to accurately and quickly file for unemployment benefits

section.class: col-lg-6 col-xl-6 col-md-6 col-sm-12 col-xs-12 block block-block-content block-block-content56fbe6d7-95b3-4313-aea8-2b138240ff3a clearfix

div.h3: What to do if you are ill
div.p: If you are ill with fever and a cough or shortness of breath, stay home. If you are unsure of how to care for yourself or are concerned about your condition, call your health care provider for advice. If you feel you need to visit your doctor, call them first. Keep yourself separated from other people and animals in your home. Cover your coughs and sneezes and wash your hands often.

ul.li: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) screening tool and guidance for steps to take if you are sick with COVID-19 or think you may be infected with coronavirus
CDC guidance to help families, employers, schools and others stop the spread of COVID-19 (pdf)
Washington State Department of Health information on getting tested

section.class: col-lg-6 col-xl-6 col-md-6 col-sm-12 col-xs-12 block block-block-content block-block-content1a7a77e8-f93b-448f-9226-13049988c434 clearfix

div.h3: Leave some for your neighbor. Don’t buy more than you need!
div.p: Washington's supply chains are operating normally, yet consumers are overstocking and clearing store shelves of the items that sick neighbors, doctors, dentists and emergency response personnel need to stay safe. Health experts emphasize the best way to protect yourself from infection is through washing your hands frequently and limiting contact with others, not by overstocking certain supplies. Leave some for the folks who need them most!

section.class: views-element-container col-xl-8 col-lg-8 col-md-8 col-sm-12 col-xs-12 block block-views block-views-blocknews-block-1 clearfix

Employment Security Department Statement regarding the launch of expanded benefits - 04/19/2020
State recalls 12,000 COVID-19 test kits due to possible contamination - 04/19/2020
